<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Given these risks and uncertainties, you are cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward-looking statements. These risks and
	uncertainties may cause our actual future results to be materially different than those expressed in our forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are made only as of the date of this Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
	We do not undertake and specifically decline any obligation to update any such statements or to publicly announce the results of any revisions to any such statements to reflect future events or developments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our business strategy is
	to acquire and develop behavioral healthcare facilities and improve our operating results within our facilities and our other behavioral healthcare operations. We strive to improve the operating results of our facilities by providing high-quality
	services, expanding referral networks and marketing initiatives while meeting the increased demand for behavioral healthcare services through expansion of our current locations as well as developing new services within existing locations. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, we operated 573 behavioral healthcare facilities with approximately 17,100 beds in 39 states, the U.K. and Puerto Rico. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, we acquired 328 facilities and added approximately 967 new
	beds (exclusive of acquisitions), including 827 to existing facilities and 140 added through the opening of two de novo facilities. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, we divested 21 existing U.K. facilities and one de novo facility. For
	the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2017, we expect to add approximately 800 total beds exclusive of acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We are the leading
	publicly traded pure-play provider of behavioral healthcare services, with operations in the United States and the United Kingdom. Management believes that the Company is positioned as a leading platform in a highly fragmented industry under the
	direction of an experienced management team that has significant industry expertise. Management expects to take advantage of several strategies that are more accessible as a result of our increased size and geographic scale, including continuing a
	national marketing strategy to attract new patients and referral sources, increasing our volume of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	out-of-state
</FONT>
</FONT>
	referrals, providing a broader range of services to new
	and existing patients and clients and selectively pursuing opportunities to expand our facility and bed count in the U.S. and U.K.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Acquisitions
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 U.S. Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	June&nbsp;1, 2016, we completed the acquisition of Pocono Mountain, an inpatient psychiatric facility with 108 beds located in Henryville, Pennsylvania, for cash consideration of approximately $25.4&nbsp;million. In addition, we may be required to
	make a cash payment of up to $5.0&nbsp;million under an
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	earn-out
</FONT>
	agreement, contingent upon achievement by Pocono Mountain of certain operating performance targets for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-year
</FONT>
	period ending May&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;1, 2016, we completed the acquisition of
	TrustPoint, an inpatient psychiatric facility with 100 beds located in Murfreesboro, Tennessee, for cash consideration of approximately $62.7&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;1, 2016, we completed the acquisition of Serenity Knolls, an inpatient psychiatric facility with 30 beds located in Forest
	Knolls, California, for cash consideration of approximately $9.7&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Priory
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, we completed the acquisition of Priory for a total purchase price of approximately $2.2&nbsp;billion, including cash
	consideration of approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion and the issuance of 4,033,561 shares of our common stock to shareholders of Priory. Priory was the leading independent provider of behavioral healthcare services in the U.K. operating 324 facilities
	with approximately 7,100 beds at the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The CMA in the U.K. reviewed our acquisition of Priory. On July&nbsp;14, 2016, the
	CMA announced that our acquisition of Priory was referred for a phase 2 investigation unless we offered acceptable undertakings to address the CMA&#146;s competition concerns relating to the provision of behavioral healthcare services in certain
	markets. On July&nbsp;28, 2016, the CMA announced that we had offered undertakings to address the CMA&#146;s concerns and that, in lieu of a phase 2 investigation, the CMA would consider our undertakings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	47
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;18, 2016, we signed a definitive agreement with BC Partners for the sale of 21
	existing U.K. behavioral health facilities and one de novo behavioral health facility with an aggregate of approximately 1,000 beds. On November&nbsp;10, 2016, the CMA accepted our undertakings to sell the U.K. Disposal Group to BC Partners and
	confirmed that the divestiture satisfied the CMA&#146;s concerns about the impact of our acquisition of Priory on competition for the provision of behavioral healthcare services in certain markets in the U.K. As a result of the CMA&#146;s acceptance
	of our undertakings, our acquisition of Priory was not referred for a phase 2 investigation. On November&nbsp;30, 2016, we completed the sale of the U.K. Disposal Group to BC Partners for &pound;320&nbsp;million cash.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 U.S. Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	December&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisition of certain facilities from MMO, including two acute inpatient behavioral health facilities with a total of 80 beds located in Jennings and Covington, Louisiana, for cash consideration of
	approximately $20.2&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;Discovery House for cash
	consideration of approximately $118.3&nbsp;million and (ii)&nbsp;Duffy&#146;s for cash consideration of approximately $29.6&nbsp;million. Discovery House operates 19 comprehensive treatment centers located in four states. Duffy&#146;s is a substance
	abuse facility with 61 beds located in Calistoga, California.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August&nbsp;31, 2015, we completed the acquisition of a controlling
	interest in&nbsp;Southcoast, an inpatient psychiatric facility located in Fairhaven, Massachusetts. The Company owns 75% of the equity interests in the facility. The value of the 25% noncontrolling interest is approximately $9.2&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisition of&nbsp;the assets of Belmont, an inpatient psychiatric facility with 147 beds located in
	Philadelphia, Pennsylvania for cash consideration of approximately $39.0&nbsp;million which consists of $35.0&nbsp;million base purchase price and a working capital settlement of $4.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;1, 2015, we acquired the stock of QAM for cash consideration of approximately $54.8&nbsp;million. QAM operates seven
	comprehensive treatment centers located in Wisconsin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;11, 2015, we completed the acquisition of CRC for total
	consideration of approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion. As consideration for the acquisition, we issued 5,975,326 shares of our common stock to certain holders of CRC common stock and repaid CRC&#146;s outstanding indebtedness of $904.5&nbsp;million. CRC
	was a leading provider of treatment services related to substance abuse and other addiction and behavioral disorders operating 35 inpatient facilities with over 2,400 beds and 81 comprehensive treatment centers located in 30 states at the
	acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 U.K. Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisition of Cleveland House, an inpatient psychiatric facility with 32 beds located in England,
	for cash consideration of approximately $10.3&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisition of Meadow View, an
	inpatient psychiatric facility with 28 beds located in England, for cash consideration of approximately $6.8&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	September&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;three facilities from Danshell for approximately $59.8&nbsp;million, (ii)&nbsp;two facilities from H&amp;SCP for approximately $26.2&nbsp;million and (iii)&nbsp;Manor Hall for
	approximately $14.0&nbsp;million. The inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from Danshell have an aggregate of 73 beds and are located in England. The inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from H&amp;SCP have an aggregate of 50 beds and are
	located in England. Manor Hall has 26 beds and is located in England.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisition of The Manor
	Clinic, a substance abuse facility with 15 beds located in England, for cash consideration of approximately $5.9&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	June&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;one facility from Choice for cash consideration of approximately $25.9&nbsp;million and (ii)&nbsp;15 facilities from Care UK for approximately $88.2&nbsp;million. The inpatient psychiatric
	facility acquired from Choice has 42 beds and is located in England. The inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from Care UK have an aggregate of 299 beds and are located in England.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	48
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage51"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;1, 2015, we completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;two facilities from Choice for
	cash consideration of approximately $37.5&nbsp;million, (ii)&nbsp;Pastoral for approximately $34.2&nbsp;million and (iii)&nbsp;Mildmay Oaks for cash consideration of approximately $14.9&nbsp;million. The two inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired
	from Choice have an aggregate of 48 beds and are located in England. Pastoral operates two inpatient psychiatric facilities with an aggregate of 65 beds located in Wales. Mildmay Oaks is an inpatient psychiatric facility with 67 beds located in
	England.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Revenue
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our revenue is
	primarily derived from services rendered to patients for inpatient psychiatric and substance abuse care, outpatient psychiatric care and adolescent residential treatment. We receive payments from the following sources for services rendered in our
	facilities: (i)&nbsp;state governments under their respective Medicaid and other programs; (ii)&nbsp;commercial insurers; (iii)&nbsp;the federal government under the Medicare program administered by CMS; (iv)&nbsp;public funded sources in the U.K.
	(including the NHS, CCGs and Local Authorities); and (v)&nbsp;individual patients and clients. Revenue is recorded in the period in which services are provided at established billing rates less contractual adjustments based on amounts reimbursable
	by Medicare or Medicaid under provisions of cost or prospective reimbursement formulas or amounts due from other third-party payors at contractually determined rates.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 Compared to the Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Revenue before provision for doubtful accounts.
</I>
	Revenue before provision for doubtful accounts increased $1.0&nbsp;billion, or 55.9%, to
	$2.9&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 from $1.8&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The increase related primarily to revenue generated during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 from the facilities
	acquired in our 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory. The decrease in the GBP to USD exchange rate had an unfavorable impact on revenue before provision for doubtful accounts of $35.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016. Same-facility revenue before provision for doubtful accounts increased by $127.2&nbsp;million, or 7.5%, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, primarily resulting from
	same-facility growth in patient days of 7.2%. Consistent with the same-facility patient day growth in 2015, the growth in same-facility patient days for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 resulted
	from the addition of beds to our existing facilities and ongoing demand for our services.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	49
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage52"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for doubtful accounts.
</I>
	The provision for doubtful accounts was
	$41.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 1.5&nbsp;% of revenue before provision for doubtful accounts, compared to $35.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 1.9% of revenue before provision for doubtful
	accounts. The same-facility provision for doubtful accounts was $35.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 1.9% of revenue before provision for doubtful accounts, compared to $31.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 1.9% of revenue before provision for doubtful accounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Salaries, wages and benefits.
</I>
	Salaries, wages
	and benefits (&#147;SWB&#148;) expense was $1.5&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to $973.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, an increase of $568.1&nbsp;million. SWB expense included
	$28.3&nbsp;million and $20.5&nbsp;million of equity-based compensation expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. Excluding equity-based compensation expense, SWB expense was $1.5&nbsp;billion, or 53.8% of revenue,
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $953.3&nbsp;million, or 53.1% of revenue, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The $560.3&nbsp;million increase in SWB expense, excluding equity-based compensation expense, was primarily
	attributable to SWB expense incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory. Same-facility SWB expense was $895.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 50.2% of
	revenue, compared to $830.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 50.0% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Professional fees.
</I>
	Professional fees were $185.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 6.6&nbsp;% of revenue, compared to $116.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 6.5% of revenue. The $69.0&nbsp;million increase was
	primarily attributable to professional fees incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory. Same-facility professional fees were $92.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016, or 5.2% of revenue, compared to $95.0&nbsp;million, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 5.7% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Supplies.
</I>
	Supplies expense was $117.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 4.2% of revenue, compared to $80.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 4.5% of revenue. The $36.7&nbsp;million increase was primarily
	attributable to supplies expense incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory. Same-facility supplies expense was $79.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 4.5%
	of revenue, compared to $74.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 4.5% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rents and leases.
</I>
	Rents
	and leases were $73.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 2.6% of revenue, compared to $32.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 1.8% of revenue. The $40.8&nbsp;million increase was primarily
	attributable to rents and leases incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory. Same-facility rents and leases were $31.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 1.8%
	of revenue, compared to $29.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 1.8% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other operating
	expenses.
</I>
	Other operating expenses consisted primarily of purchased services, utilities, insurance, travel and repairs and maintenance expenses. Other operating expenses were $312.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or
	11.1% of revenue, compared to $206.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 11.5% of revenue. The $105.9&nbsp;million increase was primarily attributable to other operating expenses incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2015
	and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory. Same-facility other operating expenses were $202.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 11.4% of revenue, compared to $188.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 11.3% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Depreciation and amortization.
</I>
	Depreciation and amortization expense was
	$135.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, or 4.8% of revenue, compared to $63.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 3.5% of revenue. The increase in depreciation and amortization was attributable to
	depreciation associated with capital expenditures during 2015 and 2016 and real estate acquired as part of the 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of Priory.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Interest expense.
</I>
	Interest expense was $181.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to $106.7&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The increase in interest expense was primarily a result of borrowings under the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility, the issuance of the 5.625% Senior Notes on February&nbsp;11, 2015 and
	September&nbsp;21, 2015 and the issuance of the 6.500% Senior Notes on February&nbsp;16, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Debt extinguishment costs.
</I>
	Debt
	extinguishment costs for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 represent $1.1&nbsp;million of cash charges and $3.2&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	charges recorded in connection with the Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment and the Refinancing Amendment.
<I>
</I>
	Debt extinguishment costs for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 represent $7.5&nbsp;million of cash charges and $3.3&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	charges recorded in connection with the repayment of $97.5&nbsp;million of 12.875% Senior Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Loss on divestiture.
</I>
	As part of our divestitures in the U.K. and U.S., we recorded $178.8&nbsp;million of loss on divestiture for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, which included an allocation of goodwill to the disposal groups of approximately $106.9&nbsp;million, loss on the sale of properties of approximately $45.0&nbsp;million, transaction-related expenses of
	approximately $26.8&nbsp;million and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of intangible assets of approximately $0.1&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	50
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage53"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	(Gain) loss on foreign currency derivatives.
</I>
	We entered into foreign currency forward
	contracts during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 in connection with (i)&nbsp;acquisitions in the U.K. and (ii)&nbsp;transfers of cash between the U.S. and the U.K. under our cash management and foreign currency risk management
	programs. Exchange rate changes between the contract date and the settlement date resulted in a gain on foreign currency derivatives of $0.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to a loss of $1.9&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Transaction-related expenses.
</I>
	Transaction-related expenses were $48.3&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to $36.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. Transaction-related expenses represent costs incurred in the respective periods, primarily related to the 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions, as
	summarized below (in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for income taxes.
</I>
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the provision for income taxes
	was $28.8&nbsp;million, reflecting an effective tax rate of 87.3%, compared to $53.4&nbsp;million, reflecting an effective tax rate of 32.4%, for 2015. The change in the tax rate for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 is primarily attributable to
	the disparity between the accounting treatment and the tax treatment of the U.K. Divestiture on November&nbsp;30, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 Compared to the Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Revenue before provision for doubtful accounts.
</I>
	Revenue before provision for doubtful accounts increased $798.8&nbsp;million, or 77.5%, to $1.8&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 from $1.0&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase related primarily
	to revenue generated during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 from the facilities acquired in our 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of CRC. Same-facility revenue before provision for doubtful accounts increased by
	$78.9&nbsp;million, or 7.8%, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily resulting from same-facility growth in patient days of 8.0%. Consistent with the same-facility patient day growth in
	2014, the growth in same-facility patient days for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 resulted from the addition of beds to our existing facilities and ongoing demand for our services.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for doubtful accounts.
</I>
	The provision for doubtful accounts was $35.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015,
	or 1.9% of revenue before provision for doubtful accounts, compared to $26.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 2.5% of revenue before provision for doubtful accounts. The same-facility provision for doubtful accounts was
	$26.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 2.4% of revenue before provision for doubtful accounts, compared to $25.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 2.5% of revenue before provision for doubtful
	accounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Salaries, wages and benefits.
</I>
	SWB expense was $973.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to
	$575.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $398.3&nbsp;million. SWB expense included $20.5&nbsp;million and $10.1&nbsp;million of equity-based compensation expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and
	2014, respectively. Excluding equity-based compensation expense, SWB expense was $953.3&nbsp;million, or 53.1% of revenue, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $565.4&nbsp;million, or 56.3% of revenue, for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. The $387.9&nbsp;million increase in SWB expense, excluding equity-based compensation expense, was primarily attributable to SWB expense incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, particularly the
	acquisition of CRC. Same-facility SWB expense was $554.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 52.3% of revenue, compared to $524.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 53.5% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Professional fees.
</I>
	Professional fees were $116.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 6.5% of revenue, compared
	to $52.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 5.2% of revenue. The $64.0&nbsp;million increase was primarily attributable to professional fees incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, particularly
	the acquisition of CRC. Same-facility professional fees were $55.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 5.2% of revenue, compared to $46.2&nbsp;million, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 4.7% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Supplies.
</I>
	Supplies expense was $80.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 4.5% of revenue, compared to
	$48.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 4.8% of revenue. The $32.3&nbsp;million increase was primarily attributable to supplies expense incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, particularly the
	acquisition of CRC. Same-facility supplies expense was $48.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 4.6% of revenue, compared to $47.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 4.8% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	51
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage54"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rents and leases.
</I>
	Rents and leases were $32.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 1.8% of revenue, compared to $12.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 1.2% of revenue. The $20.3&nbsp;million increase was primarily attributable to rents and leases incurred by the facilities
	acquired in our 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of CRC. Same-facility rents and leases were $11.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 1.1% of revenue, compared to $11.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 1.2% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other operating expenses.
</I>
	Other operating expenses consisted primarily of purchased
	services, utilities, insurance, travel and repairs and maintenance expenses. Other operating expenses were $206.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 11.5% of revenue, compared to $110.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 11.0% of revenue. The $96.0&nbsp;million increase was primarily attributable to other operating expenses incurred by the facilities acquired in our 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, particularly the acquisition of CRC.
	Same-facility other operating expenses were $120.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, or 11.3% of revenue, compared to $105.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 10.8% of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Depreciation and amortization.
</I>
	Depreciation and amortization expense was $63.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015,
	or 3.5% of revenue, compared to $32.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, or 3.3% of revenue. The increase in depreciation and amortization was attributable to depreciation associated with capital expenditures during 2014 and
	2015 and real estate acquired as part of the 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Interest expense.
</I>
	Interest expense was
	$106.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $48.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase in interest expense was primarily a result of borrowings under the Amended and Restated Senior
	Credit Facility and the issuance of the 5.625% Senior Notes on February&nbsp;11, 2015 and September&nbsp;21, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	(Gain) loss on
	foreign currency derivatives.
</I>
	In connection with the acquisition in the U.K., the Company entered into foreign currency forward contracts during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 in order to fix the exchange rate applicable to the
	payment of the acquisition purchase prices. Exchange rate changes between the contract date and the settlement date resulted in a loss on foreign currency derivatives of $1.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to a gain
	of $15.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Debt extinguishment costs.
</I>
	Debt extinguishment costs for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 represent $7.5&nbsp;million of cash charges and $3.3&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	charges recorded in connection with the repayment of $97.5&nbsp;million of 12.875% Senior Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Transaction-related expenses.
</I>
	Transaction-related expenses were $36.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared
	to $13.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Transaction-related expenses represent costs incurred in the respective periods, primarily related to the 2014 and 2015 Acquisitions, as summarized below (in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_10"></A>

<TR>

	2015
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for income taxes.
</I>
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the provision for income taxes
	was $53.4&nbsp;million, reflecting an effective tax rate of 32.4%, compared to $42.9&nbsp;million, reflecting an effective tax rate of 34.0%, for 2014. The decrease in the tax rate for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was primarily attributable
	to a full year of results for Partnerships in Care in 2015, compared to six months in 2014. Partnerships in Care is located in a lower taxing jurisdiction and for which our earnings are permanently reinvested.
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash
	provided by continuing operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $371.7&nbsp;million compared to $242.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The increase in cash provided by continuing operating activities
	was primarily attributable to cash provided by continuing operating activities from the 2015 and 2016 Acquisitions and the growth in same-facility operations. Days sales outstanding as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 was 34 compared to 40 as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2015. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had working capital of $85.1&nbsp;million and $4.5&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash used in investing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $660.4&nbsp;million compared to $884.5&nbsp;million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. Cash used in investing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 primarily consisted of $683.5&nbsp;million
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	52
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage55"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	of cash paid for acquisitions, $307.5&nbsp;million of cash paid for capital expenditures and $40.8&nbsp;million of cash paid for real estate acquisitions, partially offset by cash received on
	divestitures of $373.3&nbsp;million. Cash paid for capital expenditures for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 consisted of $76.0&nbsp;million of routine capital expenditures and $231.5&nbsp;million of expansion capital expenditures. We define
	expansion capital expenditures as those that increase the capacity of our facilities or otherwise enhance revenue. Routine or maintenance capital expenditures were approximately 2.7% of revenue for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. Cash used in
	investing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily consisted of $574.8&nbsp;million of cash paid for acquisitions, $276.0&nbsp;million of cash paid for capital expenditures and $26.6&nbsp;million of cash paid for real estate
	acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $358.8&nbsp;million compared to
	$563.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. Cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 primarily consisted of long-term debt borrowings of $1.5&nbsp;billion, borrowings on our revolving credit
	facility of $179.0&nbsp;million and an issuance of common stock of $685.1&nbsp;million, partially offset by repayment of assumed Priory debt of $1.4&nbsp;billion, payment on revolving credit facility of $337.0&nbsp;million, repayment of long-term
	debt of $200.6&nbsp;million, principal payments on long-term debt of $49.9&nbsp;million, payment of debt issuance costs of $36.6&nbsp;million and common stock withheld for minimum statutory taxes of $8.8&nbsp;million. Cash provided by financing
	activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily consisted of borrowings on long-term debt of $1.2&nbsp;billion, borrowings on our revolving credit facility of $468.0&nbsp;million, issuance of common stock of $331.3&nbsp;million and an
	excess tax benefit from equity awards of $0.3&nbsp;million, partially offset by repayment of assumed CRC debt of $904.5&nbsp;million, principal payments on our revolving credit facility of $310.0&nbsp;million, repayment of long-term debt of
	$97.5&nbsp;million, principal payments on long-term debt of $32.0&nbsp;million, payment of debt issuance costs of $26.4&nbsp;million, payment of premium for purchase of senior notes of $7.5&nbsp;million and common stock withheld for minimum
	statutory taxes of $7.8&nbsp;million. All of our debt is denominated in USD.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We had total available cash and cash equivalents of
	$57.1&nbsp;million, $11.2&nbsp;million and $94.0&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively, of which approximately $41.4&nbsp;million, $9.2&nbsp;million and $17.4&nbsp;million was held by our foreign subsidiaries,
	respectively. Our strategic plan does not require the repatriation of foreign cash in order to fund our operations in the U.S., and it is our current intention to permanently reinvest our foreign cash and cash equivalents outside of the U.S. If we
	were to repatriate foreign cash to the U.S., we would be required to accrue and pay U.S. taxes in accordance with applicable U.S. tax rules and regulations as a result of the repatriation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We entered into a Senior Secured Credit Facility (the &#147;Senior Secured Credit Facility&#148;) on April&nbsp;1, 2011. On December&nbsp;31,
	2012, we entered into the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement which amended and restated the Senior Secured Credit Facility. We have amended the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement from time to time as described in our prior filings with the
	Securities and Exchange Commission.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;6, 2015, we entered into the Seventh Amendment to our Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement. The Seventh Amendment added Citibank, N.A. as an &#147;L/C Issuer&#148; under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement in order to permit the rollover of CRC&#146;s existing letters of credit into the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement and increased both the Company&#146;s Letter of Credit Sublimit and Swing Line Sublimit to $20.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	February&nbsp;11, 2015, we entered into the First Incremental Amendment to our Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The First Incremental Amendment activated a new $500.0&nbsp;million incremental Existing TLB Facility that was added to the Amended
	and Restated Senior Secured Credit Facility, subject to limited conditionality provisions. Borrowings under the Existing TLB Facility were used to fund a portion of the purchase price for our acquisition of CRC.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;22, 2015, we entered into an Eighth Amendment to our Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Eighth Amendment changed the
	definition of &#147;Change of Control&#148; in part to remove a provision whose purpose was, when calculating whether a majority of incumbent directors have approved new directors, that any incumbent director that became a director as a result of a
	threatened or actual proxy contest was not counted in such calculation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;25, 2016, we entered into the Ninth Amendment to
	our Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Ninth Amendment modified certain definitions and provides increased flexibility to us in terms of our financial covenants. Our baskets for permitted investments were also increased to provide increased
	flexibility for us to invest in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-wholly
</FONT>
	owned subsidiaries, joint ventures and foreign subsidiaries. As a result of the Ninth Amendment, we may invest in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-wholly
</FONT>
	owned subsidiaries and joint ventures up to 10.0% of our and our subsidiaries&#146; total assets in any consecutive four fiscal quarter period, and up to 12.5% of our and our subsidiaries&#146; total assets during the term of the Amended and
	Restated Credit Agreement. We may also invest in foreign subsidiaries that are not loan parties up to 10% of our and our subsidiaries&#146; total assets in any consecutive four fiscal quarter period, and up to 15% of our and our subsidiaries&#146;
	total assets during the term of the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The foregoing permitted investments are subject to an aggregate cap of 25% of our and our subsidiaries&#146; total assets in any fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	53
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage56"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, we entered into the Second Incremental Facility Amendment to our
	Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Second Incremental Amendment activated a new $955.0&nbsp;million incremental Term Loan B facility and added $135.0&nbsp;million to the Term Loan A facility to our Amended and Restated Senior Secured Credit
	Facility, subject to limited conditionality provisions. Borrowings under the New TLB Facility were used to fund a portion of the purchase price for the acquisition of Priory and the fees and expenses for such acquisition and the related financing
	transactions. Borrowings under the TLA Facility were used to pay down the majority of our $300.0&nbsp;million revolving credit facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;26, 2016, we entered into a Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-1
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment to the Amended and Restated
	Credit Agreement. The Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-1
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment reduced the Applicable Rate with respect to the Existing TLB Facility from 3.5% to 3.0% in the case of Eurodollar Rate loans and 2.5% to 2.0% in the case
	of Base Rate Loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;21, 2016, we entered into a Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment
	to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment reduced the Applicable Rate with respect to the New TLB Facility from 3.75% to 3.00% in the case of Eurodollar Rate loans and
	2.75% to 2.00% in the case of Base Rate Loans. In connection with the Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment, we recorded a debt extinguishment charge of $3.4&nbsp;million, including the discount and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of deferred financing costs, which was recorded in debt extinguishment costs in the consolidated statements of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;22, 2016, we entered into a Tenth Amendment to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Tenth Amendment, among other
	things, (i)&nbsp;amended the negative covenant regarding dispositions, (ii)&nbsp;modified the collateral package to release any real property with a fair market value of less than $5.0&nbsp;million and (iii)&nbsp;changed certain investment,
	indebtedness and lien baskets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;30, 2016, we entered into a Refinancing Facilities Amendment to the Amended and Restated
	Credit Agreement. The Refinancing Amendment increased our line of credit on our revolving credit facility to $500.0&nbsp;million from $300.0&nbsp;million and reduced our TLA Facility to $400.0&nbsp;million from $600.6&nbsp;million. In addition, the
	Refinancing Amendment extended the maturity date for the Refinancing Facilities to November&nbsp;30, 2021 from February&nbsp;13, 2019, and lowered our effective interest rate on our line of credit on our revolving credit facility and TLA Facility by
	50 basis points. In connection with the Refinancing Amendment, we recorded a debt extinguishment charge of $0.8&nbsp;million, including the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of deferred financing costs, which was recorded in debt
	extinguishment costs in the consolidated statements of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We had $491.7&nbsp;million of availability under the revolving line of
	credit and had standby letters of credit outstanding of $8.3&nbsp;million related to security for the payment of claims required by our workers&#146; compensation insurance program as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. Borrowings under the revolving line of
	credit are subject to customary conditions precedent to borrowing. The Amended and Restated Credit Agreement requires quarterly term loan principal repayments of our TLA Facility of $5.0&nbsp;million for March&nbsp;31, 2017 to December&nbsp;31,
	2019, $7.5&nbsp;million for March&nbsp;31, 2020 to December&nbsp;31, 2020, and $10.0&nbsp;million for March&nbsp;31, 2021 to September&nbsp;30, 2021, with the remaining principal balance of the TLA Facility due on the maturity date of
	November&nbsp;30, 2021. We are required to repay the Existing TLB Facility in equal quarterly installments of $1.3&nbsp;million on the last business day of each March, June, September and December, with the outstanding principal balance of the
	Existing TLB Facility due on February&nbsp;11, 2022. We are required to repay the New TLB Facility in equal quarterly installments of approximately $2.4&nbsp;million on the last business day of each March, June, September and December, with the
	outstanding principal balance of the New TLB Facility due on February&nbsp;16, 2023.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Borrowings under the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement are guaranteed by each of our wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries (other than certain excluded subsidiaries) and are secured by a lien on substantially all of our and such subsidiaries&#146; assets. Borrowings with respect to the TLA
	Facility and our revolving credit facility (collectively, &#147;Pro Rata Facilities&#148;) under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement bear interest at a rate tied to Acadia&#146;s Consolidated Leverage Ratio (defined as consolidated funded debt
	net of up to $40.0&nbsp;million of unrestricted and unencumbered cash to consolidated EBITDA, in each case as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement). The Applicable Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) for
	the Pro Rata Facilities was 2.75% for Eurodollar Rate Loans (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) and 1.75% for Base Rate Loans (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Eurodollar Rate
	Loans with respect to the Pro Rata Facilities bear interest at the Applicable Rate plus the Eurodollar Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) (based upon the LIBOR Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement) prior to commencement of the interest rate period). Base Rate Loans with respect to the Pro Rata Facilities bear interest at the Applicable Rate plus the highest of (i)&nbsp;the federal funds rate plus 0.50%, (ii)&nbsp;the prime rate and
	(iii)&nbsp;the Eurodollar Rate plus 1.0%. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Pro Rata Facilities bore interest at a rate of LIBOR plus 2.75%. In addition, we are required to pay a commitment fee on undrawn amounts under our revolving credit facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	54
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The interest rates and the unused line fee on unused commitments related to the Pro Rata
	Facilities are based upon the following pricing tiers:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Eurodollar Rate Loans with respect to the Existing TLB Facility bear interest at the Existing TLB Applicable
	Rate (as defined below) plus the Eurodollar Rate (subject to a floor of 0.75% and based upon the LIBOR Rate prior to commencement of the interest rate period). Base Rate Loans bear interest at the Existing TLB Applicable Rate plus the highest of
	(i)&nbsp;the federal funds rate plus 0.50%, (ii)&nbsp;the prime rate and (iii)&nbsp;the Eurodollar Rate plus 1.0%. As used herein, the term &#147;Existing TLB Applicable Rate&#148; means, with respect to Eurodollar Rate Loans, 3.0%, and with respect
	to Base Rate Loans, 2.0%. The New TLB Facility bears interest as follows: Eurodollar Rate Loans bear interest at the Applicable Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) plus the Eurodollar Rate (subject to a floor of 0.75% and
	based upon the LIBOR Rate prior to commencement of the interest rate period) and Base Rate Loans bear interest at the Applicable Rate plus the highest of (i)&nbsp;the federal funds rate plus 0.50%, (ii)&nbsp;the prime rate and (iii)&nbsp;the
	Eurodollar Rate plus 1.0%. As used herein, the term &#147;Applicable Rate&#148; means, with respect to Eurodollar Rate Loans, 3.0%, and with respect to Base Rate Loans, 2.0%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The lenders who provided the Existing TLB Facility and New TLB Facility are not entitled to benefit from the Company&#146;s maintenance of its
	financial covenants under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. Accordingly, if we fail to maintain its financial covenants, such failure shall not constitute an event of default under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement with respect to
	the Existing TLB Facility or the New TLB Facility until and unless the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility is accelerated or the commitment of the lenders to make further loans is terminated.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Amended and Restated Credit Agreement requires us and our subsidiaries to comply with customary affirmative, negative and financial
	covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio, consolidated leverage ratio and consolidated senior secured leverage ratio. We may be required to pay all of our indebtedness immediately if we default on any of the numerous financial or other
	restrictive covenants contained in any of its material debt agreements. We may be required to pay all of our indebtedness immediately if we default on any of the numerous financial or other restrictive covenants contained in any of our material debt
	agreements. Set forth below is a brief description of such covenants, all of which are subject to customary exceptions, materiality thresholds and qualifications:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the affirmative covenants include the following: (i)&nbsp;delivery of financial statements and other customary financial information; (ii)&nbsp;notices of events of default and other material events;
	(iii)&nbsp;maintenance of existence, ability to conduct business, properties, insurance and books and records; (iv)&nbsp;payment of taxes; (v)&nbsp;lender inspection rights; (vi)&nbsp;compliance with laws; (vii)&nbsp;use of proceeds;
	(viii)&nbsp;further assurances; and (ix)&nbsp;additional collateral and guarantor requirements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the negative covenants include limitations on the following: (i)&nbsp;liens; (ii) debt (including guaranties); (iii) investments; (iv)&nbsp;fundamental changes (including mergers, consolidations and liquidations); (v)
	dispositions; (vi)&nbsp;sale leasebacks; (vii)&nbsp;affiliate transactions; (viii)&nbsp;burdensome agreements; (ix)&nbsp;restricted payments; (x)&nbsp;use of proceeds; (xi)&nbsp;ownership of subsidiaries; (xii)&nbsp;changes to line of business;
	(xiii)&nbsp;changes to organizational documents, legal name, state of formation, form of entity and fiscal year; (xiv)&nbsp;prepayment or redemption of certain senior unsecured debt; and (xv)&nbsp;amendments to certain material agreements. The
	Company is generally not permitted to issue dividends or distributions other than with respect to the following: (w)&nbsp;certain tax distributions; (x)&nbsp;the repurchase of equity held by employees, officers or directors upon the occurrence of
	death, disability or termination subject to cap of $500,000 in any fiscal year and compliance with certain other conditions; (y)&nbsp;in the form of capital stock; and (z)&nbsp;scheduled payments of deferred purchase price, working capital
	adjustments and similar payments pursuant to the merger agreement or any permitted acquisition.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	c)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The financial covenants include maintenance of the following:
</TD>
</TR>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company was in compliance with all of the above covenants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	6.125% Senior
	Notes Due 2021
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;12, 2013, we issued $150.0&nbsp;million of 6.125% Senior Notes due 2021. The 6.125% Senior Notes
	mature on March&nbsp;15, 2021 and bear interest at a rate of 6.125%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on March&nbsp;15 and September&nbsp;15 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	5.125% Senior Notes due 2022
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2014, we issued $300.0&nbsp;million of 5.125% Senior Notes due 2022. The 5.125% Senior Notes mature on July&nbsp;1, 2022 and
	bear interest at a rate of 5.125%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on January&nbsp;1 and July&nbsp;1 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	5.625% Senior Notes due 2023
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;11, 2015, we issued $375.0&nbsp;million of 5.625% Senior Notes due 2023. On September&nbsp;21, 2015, we issued
	$275.0&nbsp;million of additional 5.625% Senior Notes. The additional notes formed a single class of debt securities with the 5.625% Senior Notes issued in February 2015. Giving effect to this issuance, we have outstanding an aggregate of
	$650.0&nbsp;million of 5.625% Senior Notes. The 5.625% Senior Notes mature on February&nbsp;15, 2023 and bear interest at a rate of 5.625%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on February&nbsp;15 and August&nbsp;15 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	6.500% Senior Notes due 2024
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, we issued $390.0&nbsp;million of 6.500% Senior Notes due 2024. The 6.500% Senior Notes mature on March&nbsp;1, 2024
	and bear interest at a rate of 6.500%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on March&nbsp;1 and September&nbsp;1 of each year, beginning on September&nbsp;1, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The indentures governing the Senior Notes contain covenants that, among other things, limit the Company&#146;s ability and the ability of its
	restricted subsidiaries to: (i)&nbsp;pay dividends, redeem stock or make other distributions or investments; (ii)&nbsp;incur additional debt or issue certain preferred stock; (iii)&nbsp;transfer or sell assets; (iv)&nbsp;engage in certain
	transactions with affiliates; (v)&nbsp;create restrictions on dividends or other payments by the restricted subsidiaries; (vi)&nbsp;merge, consolidate or sell substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets; and (vii)&nbsp;create liens on assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Senior Notes issued by the Company are guaranteed by each of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries that guarantee the Company&#146;s
	obligations under the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility. The guarantees are full and unconditional and joint and several.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	56
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company may redeem the Senior Notes at its option, in whole or part, at the dates and amounts
	set forth in the indentures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;11, 2012, in connection with the acquisition of The Pavilion at HealthPark, LLC (&#147;Park Royal&#148;), we assumed debt of
	$23.0&nbsp;million. The fair market value of the debt assumed was $25.6&nbsp;million and resulted in a debt premium balance being recorded as of the acquisition date. The debt consisted of $7.5&nbsp;million and $15.5&nbsp;million of Lee County
	(Florida) Industrial Development Authority Healthcare Facilities Revenue Bonds, Series 2010 with stated interest rates of 9.0% and 9.5%, respectively. The 9.0% bonds in the amount of $7.5&nbsp;million have a maturity date of December&nbsp;1, 2030
	and require yearly principal payments beginning in 2013. The 9.5% bonds in the amount of $15.5&nbsp;million have a maturity date of December&nbsp;1, 2040 and require yearly principal payments beginning in 2031. The principal payments establish a
	bond-sinking fund to be held with the trustee and shall be sufficient to redeem the principal amounts of the 9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds on their respective maturity dates. As of September&nbsp;30, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, $2.3&nbsp;million
	was recorded within other assets on the consolidated balance sheets related to the debt service reserve fund requirements. The yearly principal payments, which establish a bond sinking fund, will increase the debt service reserve fund requirements.
	The bond premium amount of $2.6&nbsp;million is amortized as a reduction of interest expense over the life of the 9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds using the effective interest method.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Balance
</FONT>
	Sheet Arrangements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had standby letters of credit outstanding of $8.3&nbsp;million related to security for the payment of claims
	as required by our workers&#146; compensation insurance program.
</P>
</EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<EFX_MARKET_RISK>
<A NAME="FIS_MARKET_RISK"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Market Risk
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our interest expense is sensitive to changes in market interest rates. Our long-term debt outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2016 was composed of
	$1.5&nbsp;billion of fixed-rate debt and $1.8&nbsp;billion of variable-rate debt with interest based on LIBOR plus an applicable margin. A hypothetical 10% increase in interest rates (which would equate to a 0.37% higher rate on our variable rate
	debt) would decrease our net income and cash flows by $4.3&nbsp;million on an annual basis based upon our borrowing level at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The functional currency for our U.K. facilities is the British pound (&#147;GBP&#148;). Our revenue and earnings are sensitive to changes in
	the GBP to USD exchange rate from the translation of our earnings into USD at exchange rates that may fluctuate. On a pro forma basis for the Priory acquisition and U.K. Divestiture, based upon the level of our U.K. operations relative to the
	Company as a whole, a hypothetical 10% change (which would equate to an increase or decrease in the exchange rate of 0.14) would cause a change in our net income of $12.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. In May 2016, we
	entered into multiple cross currency swap agreements with an aggregate notional amount of $650.0&nbsp;million to manage foreign currency exchange risk by effectively converting a portion of our fixed-rate USD denominated senior notes, including the
	semi-annual interest payments thereunder, to fixed-rate,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	GBP-denominated
</FONT>
	debt of &pound;449.3&nbsp;million. The cross currency swap agreements limit the impact of changes in the exchange rate on our cash flows
	and leverage. Following the Brexit vote, the GBP dropped to its lowest level against the USD in more than 30&nbsp;years. If the exchange rate remains low, our results of operations will be negatively impacted in future periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our
	consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the U.S. In preparing our financial statements, we are required to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	57
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	assets, liabilities, revenue, and expenses included in the financial statements. Estimates are based on historical experience and other available information, the results of which form the basis
	of such estimates. While management believes our estimation processes are reasonable, actual results could differ from our estimates. The following accounting policies are considered critical to the portrayal of our financial condition and operating
	performance and involve highly subjective and complex assumptions and assessments:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Revenue and Accounts Receivable
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our revenue is primarily derived from services rendered to patients for inpatient psychiatric and substance abuse care, outpatient psychiatric
	care and adolescent residential treatment. We receive payments from the following sources for services rendered in our facilities: (i)&nbsp;state governments under their respective Medicaid and other programs; (ii)&nbsp;commercial insurers;
	(iii)&nbsp;the federal government under the Medicare program administered by CMS; (iv)&nbsp;public funded sources in the U.K. (including the NHS, CCGs and Local Authorities); and (v)&nbsp;individual patients and clients. Revenue is recorded in the
	period in which services are provided at established billing rates less contractual adjustments based on amounts reimbursable by Medicare or Medicaid under provisions of cost or prospective reimbursement formulas or amounts due from other
	third-party payors at contractually determined rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table presents revenue by payor type and as a percentage of revenue
	before provision for doubtful accounts for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 (in thousands):
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Medicaid accounts receivable as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 included approximately $1.2&nbsp;million
	and $1.1&nbsp;million, respectively, of accounts pending Medicaid approval.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
