<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Approximately 1.1&nbsp;million, 0.8&nbsp;million and 0.7&nbsp;million shares of common stock issuable upon
	exercise of outstanding stock options were excluded from the calculation of diluted earnings per share for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively, because their effect would have been anti-dilutive.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	4. Acquisitions
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 U.S. Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;1, 2016, the Company completed the acquisition of Pocono Mountain Recovery Center (&#147;Pocono Mountain&#148;), an
	inpatient psychiatric facility with 108 beds located in Henryville, Pennsylvania, for cash consideration of approximately $25.4&nbsp;million. In addition, the Company may be required to make a cash payment of up to $5.0&nbsp;million under an
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	earn-out
</FONT>
	agreement, contingent upon achievement by Pocono Mountain of certain operating performance targets for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-year
</FONT>
	period ending May&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-16
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage89"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;1, 2016, the Company completed the acquisition of TrustPoint Hospital
	(&#147;TrustPoint&#148;), an inpatient psychiatric facility with 100 beds located in Murfreesboro, Tennessee, for cash consideration of approximately $62.7&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;1, 2016, the Company completed the acquisition of Serenity Knolls (&#147;Serenity Knolls&#148;), an inpatient psychiatric
	facility with 30 beds located in Forest Knolls, California, for cash consideration of approximately $9.7&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Priory
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, the Company completed the acquisition of Priory Group No.&nbsp;1 Limited (&#147;Priory&#148;) for a total purchase
	price of approximately $2.2&nbsp;billion, including cash consideration of approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion and the issuance of 4,033,561 shares of its common stock to shareholders of Priory. Priory was the leading independent provider of behavioral
	healthcare services in the U.K. operating 324 facilities with approximately 7,100 beds at February&nbsp;16, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Competition and
	Markets Authority (the &#147;CMA&#148;) in the U.K. reviewed the Company&#146;s acquisition of Priory. On July&nbsp;14, 2016, the CMA announced that the Company&#146;s acquisition of Priory was referred for a phase 2 investigation unless the Company
	offered acceptable undertakings to address the CMA&#146;s competition concerns relating to the provision of behavioral healthcare services in certain markets. On July&nbsp;28, 2016, the CMA announced that the Company had offered undertakings to
	address the CMA&#146;s concerns and that, in lieu of a phase 2 investigation, the CMA would consider the Company&#146;s undertakings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	October&nbsp;18, 2016, the Company signed a definitive agreement with BC Partners (&#147;BC Partners&#148;) for the sale of 21 existing U.K. behavioral health facilities and one de novo behavioral health facility with an aggregate of approximately
	1,000 beds (collectively, the &#147;U.K. Disposal Group&#148;). On November&nbsp;10, 2016, the CMA accepted the Company&#146;s undertakings to sell the U.K. Disposal Group to BC Partners and confirmed that the divestiture satisfied the CMA&#146;s
	concerns about the impact of the Company&#146;s acquisition of Priory on competition for the provision of behavioral healthcare services in certain markets in the U.K. As a result of the CMA&#146;s acceptance of the undertakings, the Company&#146;s
	acquisition of Priory was not referred for a phase 2 investigation. On November&nbsp;30, 2016, the Company completed the sale of the U.K. Disposal Group to BC Partners for &pound;320&nbsp;million cash (the &#147;U.K. Divestiture&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In conjunction with the sale, the Company recorded a loss on divestiture of $175.0&nbsp;million in the consolidated statements of income for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016. The loss on divestiture consisted of an allocation of goodwill to the U.K. Disposal Group of $106.9&nbsp;million, loss on the sale of properties of $42.0&nbsp;million and estimated transaction-related expenses
	of $26.1&nbsp;million. The allocation of goodwill was based on the fair value of the U.K. Disposal Group relative to the total fair value of the Company&#146;s U.K. Facilities segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The consolidated statements of income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 include revenue of $154.7&nbsp;million and income from
	continuing operations before income taxes of $81.2&nbsp;million related to the U.K. Disposal Group excluding the loss on divestiture. The consolidated statements of income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 include revenue of
	$58.5&nbsp;million and income from continuing operations before income taxes of $17.0&nbsp;million related to the U.K. Disposal Group excluding the loss on divestiture.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 U.S. Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	December&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of certain facilities from MMO Behavioral Health Systems (&#147;MMO&#148;), including two acute inpatient behavioral health facilities with a total of 80 beds located in Jennings and
	Covington, Louisiana, for cash consideration of approximately $20.2&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the
	acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;Discovery House-Group Inc.&nbsp;(&#147;Discovery House&#148;) for cash consideration of approximately $118.3&nbsp;million and (ii)&nbsp;Duffy&#146;s Napa Valley Rehab&nbsp;(&#147;Duffy&#146;s&#148;) for cash consideration of
	approximately $29.6&nbsp;million. Discovery House operates 19 comprehensive treatment centers located in four states. Duffy&#146;s is a substance abuse facility with 61 beds located in Calistoga, California.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of a controlling interest in&nbsp;Southcoast Behavioral
	(&#147;Southcoast&#148;), an inpatient psychiatric facility located in Fairhaven, Massachusetts. The Company owns 75% of the equity interests in the facility. The value of the 25% noncontrolling interest is approximately $9.2&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of&nbsp;the assets of Belmont Behavioral Health (&#147;Belmont&#148;), an
	inpatient psychiatric facility with 147 beds located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania for cash consideration of approximately $39.0&nbsp;million which consists of $35.0&nbsp;million base purchase price and a working capital settlement of
	$4.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-17
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage90"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company acquired the stock of Quality Addiction Management, Inc.
	(&#147;QAM&#148;) for cash consideration of approximately $54.8&nbsp;million. QAM operates seven comprehensive treatment centers located in Wisconsin.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;11, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of CRC Health Group, Inc. (&#147;CRC&#148;) for total consideration of
	approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion. As consideration for the acquisition, the Company issued 5,975,326 shares of its common stock to certain holders of CRC common stock and repaid CRC&#146;s outstanding indebtedness of $904.5&nbsp;million. CRC was a
	leading provider of treatment services related to substance abuse and other addiction and behavioral disorders operating 35 inpatient facilities with over 2,400 beds and 81 comprehensive treatment centers located in 30 states at the acquisition
	date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 U.K. Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of Cleveland House (&#147;Cleveland House&#148;), an inpatient psychiatric
	facility with 32 beds located in England, for cash consideration of approximately $10.3&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;1, 2015, the
	Company completed the acquisition of Meadow View (&#147;Meadow View&#148;), an inpatient psychiatric facility with 28 beds located in England, for cash consideration of approximately $6.8&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;three facilities from The Danshell Group (&#147;Danshell&#148;)
	for approximately $59.8&nbsp;million, (ii)&nbsp;two facilities from Health and Social Care Partnerships (&#147;H&amp;SCP&#148;) for approximately $26.2&nbsp;million and (iii)&nbsp;Manor Hall (&#147;Manor Hall&#148;) for approximately
	$14.0&nbsp;million. The inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from Danshell have an aggregate of 73 beds and are located in England. The inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from H&amp;SCP have an aggregate of 50 beds and are located in
	England. Manor Hall has 26 beds and is located in England.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of The Manor
	Clinic (&#147;The Manor Clinic&#148;), a substance abuse facility with 15 beds located in England, for cash consideration of approximately $5.9&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;one facility from Choice Lifestyles (&#147;Choice&#148;) for cash
	consideration of approximately $25.9&nbsp;million and (ii)&nbsp;15 facilities from Care UK Limited (&#147;Care UK&#148;) for approximately $88.2&nbsp;million. The inpatient psychiatric facility acquired from Choice has 42 beds and is located in
	England. The inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from Care UK have an aggregate of 299 beds and are located in England.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	April&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company completed the acquisitions of (i)&nbsp;two facilities from Choice for cash consideration of approximately $37.5&nbsp;million, (ii)&nbsp;Pastoral Care Group (&#147;Pastoral&#148;) for approximately $34.2&nbsp;million
	and (iii)&nbsp;Mildmay Oaks f/k/a Vista Independent Hospital (&#147;Mildmay Oaks&#148;) for cash consideration of approximately $14.9&nbsp;million. The two inpatient psychiatric facilities acquired from Choice have an aggregate of 48 beds and are
	located in England. Pastoral operates two inpatient psychiatric facilities with an aggregate of 65 beds located in Wales. Mildmay Oaks is an inpatient psychiatric facility with 67 beds located in England.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Summary of Acquisitions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company selectively seeks opportunities to expand and diversify its base of operations by acquiring additional facilities. Approximately $319.4&nbsp;million of the goodwill associated with domestic acquisitions completed in 2016 and 2015 is
	deductible for federal income tax purposes. The fair values assigned to certain assets and liabilities assumed by the Company have been estimated on a preliminary basis and are subject to change as new facts and circumstances emerge that were
	present at the date of acquisition. Specifically, the Company is further assessing the valuation of certain real property and intangible assets and certain tax matters as well as certain receivables and assumed liabilities of Pocono Mountain,
	TrustPoint, Serenity Knolls and Priory.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-18
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage91"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The qualitative factors comprising the goodwill acquired in the CRC, QAM, Choice, Pastoral, Mildmay Oaks, Care UK, The Manor Clinic, Belmont,
	Southcoast, Danshell, H&amp;SCP, Manor Hall, Meadow View, Cleveland House, Duffy&#146;s, Discovery House, MMO, Priory, Serenity Knolls, TrustPoint and Pocono Mountain acquisitions (collectively the &#147;2015 and 2016 Acquisitions&#148;) include
	efficiencies derived through synergies expected by the elimination of certain redundant corporate functions and expenses, the ability to leverage call center referrals to a broader provider base, coordination of services provided across the combined
	network of facilities, achievement of operating efficiencies by benchmarking performance, and applying best practices throughout the combined companies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-19
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Pro Forma Information
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The consolidated statements of income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 included revenue of $1.5&nbsp;billion and income from
	continuing operations before income taxes of $74.8&nbsp;million for acquisitions completed in 2016. The consolidated statements of income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 included revenue of $552.1&nbsp;million and income from continuing
	operations before income taxes of $204.1&nbsp;million for acquisitions completed in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amortization expense related to definite-lived intangible assets was $0.4&nbsp;million, $0.5&nbsp;million and
	$0.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, all the Company&#146;s defined-lived intangible assets are fully amortized. The Company&#146;s licenses and accreditations,
	trade names and certificate of need intangible assets have indefinite lives and are, therefore, not subject to amortization.
</P>

	F-20

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company entered into a senior secured credit facility (the &#147;Senior Secured Credit Facility&#148;) on April&nbsp;1, 2011. On
	December&nbsp;31, 2012, the Company entered into an Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the &#147;Amended and Restated Credit Agreement&#148;) which amended and restated the Senior Secured Credit Facility (the &#147;Amended and Restated Senior
	Credit Facility&#148;). The Company has amended the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement from time to time as described in the Company&#146;s prior filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;6, 2015, the Company entered into a Seventh Amendment (the &#147;Seventh Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement. The Seventh Amendment added Citibank, N.A. as an &#147;L/C Issuer&#148; under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement in order to permit the rollover of CRC&#146;s existing letters of credit into the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement and increased both the Company&#146;s Letter of Credit Sublimit and Swing Line Sublimit to $20.0&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	February&nbsp;11, 2015, the Company entered into a First Incremental Facility Amendment (the &#147;First Incremental Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The First Incremental Amendment activated a new $500.0&nbsp;million
	incremental Term Loan B facility (the &#147;Existing TLB Facility&#148;) that was added to the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility, subject to limited conditionality provisions. Borrowings under the Existing TLB Facility were used to fund a
	portion of the purchase price for the acquisition of CRC.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;22, 2015, the Company entered into an Eighth Amendment (the
	&#147;Eighth Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Eighth Amendment changed the definition of &#147;Change of Control&#148; in part to remove a provision whose purpose was, when calculating whether a majority of
	incumbent directors have approved new directors, that any incumbent director that became a director as a result of a threatened or actual proxy contest was not counted in such calculation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;25, 2016, the Company entered into the Ninth Amendment (the &#147;Ninth Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement. The Ninth Amendment modified certain definitions and provided increased flexibility to the Company in terms of its financial covenants. The Company&#146;s baskets for permitted investments were also increased to provide increased
	flexibility for it to invest in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-wholly
</FONT>
	owned subsidiaries, joint ventures and foreign subsidiaries. The Company may now invest in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-wholly
</FONT>
	owned subsidiaries and
	joint ventures up to 10.0% of the Company and its subsidiaries&#146; total assets in any four consecutive fiscal quarter period, and up to 12.5% of the Company and its subsidiaries&#146; total assets during the term of the Amended and Restated
	Credit Agreement. The Company may also invest in foreign subsidiaries that are not loan parties up to 10% of the Company and its subsidiaries&#146; total assets in any consecutive four fiscal quarter period, and up to 15% of the Company and its
	subsidiaries&#146; total assets during the term of the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The foregoing permitted investments are subject to an aggregate cap of 25% of the Company and its subsidiaries&#146; total assets in any fiscal year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, the Company entered into a Second Incremental Facility Amendment (the &#147;Second Incremental Amendment&#148;) to
	the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Second Incremental Amendment activated a new $955.0&nbsp;million incremental Term Loan B facility (the &#147;New TLB Facility&#148;) and added $135.0&nbsp;million to the Term Loan A facility (the
	&#147;TLA Facility&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility, subject to limited conditionality provisions. Borrowings under the New
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-21
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage94"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	TLB Facility were used to fund a portion of the purchase price for the acquisition of Priory and the fees and expenses for such acquisition and the related financing transactions. Borrowings
	under the TLA Facility were used to pay down the majority of our $300.0&nbsp;million revolving credit facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;26, 2016, the
	Company entered into a Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-1
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment (the &#147;Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-1
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-1
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment reduced the Applicable Rate with respect to the Existing TLB Facility from 3.5% to 3.0% in the case of Eurodollar Rate loans and 2.5% to 2.0% in the case of Base Rate Loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;21, 2016, the Company entered into a Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment (the
	&#147;Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment reduced the Applicable Rate with respect
	to the New TLB Facility from 3.75% to 3.0% in the case of Eurodollar Rate loans and 2.75% to 2.0% in the case of Base Rate Loans. In connection with the Tranche
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	B-2
</FONT>
	Repricing Amendment, the Company recorded a
	debt extinguishment charge of $3.4&nbsp;million, including the discount and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of deferred financing costs, which was recorded in debt extinguishment costs in the consolidated statements of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;22, 2016, the Company entered into a Tenth Amendment (the &#147;Tenth Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit
	Agreement. The Tenth Amendment, among other things, (i)&nbsp;amended the negative covenant regarding dispositions, (ii)&nbsp;modified the collateral package to release any real property with a fair market value of less than $5.0&nbsp;million and
	(iii)&nbsp;changed certain investment, indebtedness and lien baskets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;30, 2016, the Company entered into a Refinancing
	Facilities Amendment (the &#147;Refinancing Amendment&#148;) to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Refinancing Amendment increased the Company&#146;s line of credit on its revolving credit facility to $500.0&nbsp;million from
	$300.0&nbsp;million and reduced its TLA Facility to $400.0&nbsp;million from $600.6&nbsp;million (together, the &#147;Refinancing Facilities&#148;). In addition, the Refinancing Amendment extended the maturity date for the Refinancing Facilities to
	November&nbsp;30, 2021 from February&nbsp;13, 2019, and lowered the Company&#146;s effective interest rate on the line of credit on its revolving credit facility and TLA Facility by 50 basis points. In connection with the Refinancing Amendment, the
	Company recorded a debt extinguishment charge of $0.8&nbsp;million, including the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of deferred financing costs, which was recorded in debt extinguishment in the consolidated statements of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company had $491.7&nbsp;million of availability under the revolving line of credit and had standby letters of credit outstanding of
	$8.3&nbsp;million related to security for the payment of claims required by its workers&#146; compensation insurance program as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. Borrowings under the revolving line of credit are subject to customary conditions precedent to
	borrowing. The Amended and Restated Credit Agreement requires quarterly term loan principal repayments of our TLA Facility of $5.0&nbsp;million for March&nbsp;31, 2017 to December&nbsp;31, 2019, $7.5&nbsp;million for March&nbsp;31, 2020 to
	December&nbsp;31, 2020, and $10.0&nbsp;million for March&nbsp;31, 2021 to September&nbsp;30, 2021, with the remaining principal balance of the TLA Facility due on the maturity date of November&nbsp;30, 2021. The Company is required to repay the
	Existing TLB Facility in equal quarterly installments of $1.3&nbsp;million on the last business day of each March, June, September and December, with the outstanding principal balance of the Existing TLB Facility due on February&nbsp;11, 2022. The
	Company is required to repay the New TLB Facility in equal quarterly installments of approximately $2.4&nbsp;million on the last business day of each March, June, September and December, with the outstanding principal balance of the TLB Facility due
	on February&nbsp;16, 2023.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Borrowings under the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility are guaranteed by each of the Company&#146;s
	wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries (other than certain excluded subsidiaries) and are secured by a lien on substantially all of the assets of the Company and such subsidiaries. Borrowings with respect to the TLA Facility and the Company&#146;s
	revolving credit facility (collectively, &#147;Pro Rata Facilities&#148;) under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement bear interest at a rate tied to Acadia&#146;s Consolidated Leverage Ratio (defined as consolidated funded debt net of up to
	$40.0&nbsp;million of unrestricted and unencumbered cash to consolidated EBITDA, in each case as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement). The Applicable Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) for the Pro Rata
	Facilities was 2.75% for Eurodollar Rate Loans (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) and 1.75% for Base Rate Loans (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Eurodollar Rate Loans with
	respect to the Pro Rata Facilities bear interest at the Applicable Rate plus the Eurodollar Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) (based upon the LIBOR Rate (as defined in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) prior to
	commencement of the interest rate period). Base Rate Loans with respect to the Pro Rata Facilities bear interest at the Applicable Rate plus the highest of (i)&nbsp;the federal funds rate plus 0.50%, (ii)&nbsp;the prime rate and (iii)&nbsp;the
	Eurodollar Rate plus 1.0%. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Pro Rata Facilities bore interest at a rate of LIBOR plus 2.75%. In addition, the Company is required to pay a commitment fee on undrawn amounts under the revolving line of credit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Amended and Restated Credit Agreement requires the Company and its subsidiaries to comply with customary affirmative, negative and
	financial covenants, including a fixed charge coverage ratio, consolidated leverage ratio and senior secured leverage ratio. The Company may be required to pay all of its indebtedness immediately if it defaults on any of the numerous financial or
	other restrictive covenants contained in any of its material debt agreements. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company was in compliance with such covenants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-22
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage95"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">

</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	6.125% Senior Notes due 2021
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;12, 2013, the Company issued $150.0&nbsp;million of 6.125% Senior Notes due 2021 (the &#147;6.125% Senior Notes&#148;). The
	6.125% Senior Notes mature on March&nbsp;15, 2021 and bear interest at a rate of 6.125%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on March&nbsp;15 and September&nbsp;15 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	5.125% Senior Notes due 2022
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2014, the Company issued $300.0&nbsp;million of 5.125% Senior Notes due 2022 (the &#147;5.125% Senior Notes&#148;). The 5.125%
	Senior Notes mature on July&nbsp;1, 2022 and bear interest at a rate of 5.125%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on January&nbsp;1 and July&nbsp;1 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	5.625% Senior Notes due 2023
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;11, 2015, the Company issued $375.0&nbsp;million of 5.625% Senior Notes due 2023 (the &#147;5.625% Senior Notes&#148;). On
	September&nbsp;21, 2015, the Company issued $275.0&nbsp;million of additional 5.625% Senior Notes. The additional notes formed a single class of debt securities with the 5.625% Senior Notes issued in February 2015. Giving effect to this issuance,
	the Company has outstanding an aggregate of $650.0&nbsp;million of 5.625% Senior Notes. The 5.625% Senior Notes mature on February&nbsp;15, 2023 and bear interest at a rate of 5.625%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on
	February&nbsp;15 and August&nbsp;15 of each year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	6.500% Senior Notes due 2024
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, the Company issued $390.0&nbsp;million of 6.500% Senior Notes due 2024 (the &#147;6.500% Senior Notes&#148;). The
	6.500% Senior Notes mature on March&nbsp;1, 2024 and bear interest at a rate of 6.500%&nbsp;per annum, payable semi-annually in arrears on March&nbsp;1 and September&nbsp;1 of each year, beginning on September&nbsp;1, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The indentures governing the 6.125% Senior Notes, 5.125% Senior Notes, 5.625% Senior Notes and 6.500% Senior Notes (together, the &#147;Senior
	Notes&#148;) contain covenants that, among other things, limit the Company&#146;s ability and the ability of its restricted subsidiaries to: (i)&nbsp;pay dividends, redeem stock or make other distributions or investments; (ii)&nbsp;incur additional
	debt or issue certain preferred stock; (iii)&nbsp;transfer or sell assets; (iv)&nbsp;engage in certain transactions with affiliates; (v)&nbsp;create restrictions on dividends or other payments by the restricted subsidiaries; (vi)&nbsp;merge,
	consolidate or sell substantially all of the Company&#146;s assets; and (vii)&nbsp;create liens on assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Senior Notes issued by the
	Company are guaranteed by each of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries that guarantee the Company&#146;s obligations under the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility. The guarantees are full and unconditional and joint and several.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company may redeem the Senior Notes at its option, in whole or part, at the dates and amounts set forth in the indentures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;11, 2012, in connection with the acquisition of Park Royal, the Company assumed debt of $23.0&nbsp;million. The fair market
	value of the debt assumed was $25.6&nbsp;million and resulted in a debt premium balance being recorded as of the acquisition date. The debt consisted of $7.5&nbsp;million and $15.5&nbsp;million of Lee County (Florida) Industrial Development
	Authority Healthcare Facilities Revenue Bonds, Series 2010 with stated interest rates of 9.0% and 9.5% (&#147;9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds&#148;), respectively. The 9.0% bonds in the amount of $7.5&nbsp;million have a maturity date of
	December&nbsp;1, 2030 and require yearly principal payments beginning in 2013. The 9.5% bonds in the amount of $15.5&nbsp;million have a maturity date of December&nbsp;1, 2040 and require yearly principal payments beginning in 2031. The principal
	payments establish a bond sinking fund to be held with the trustee and shall be sufficient to redeem the principal amounts of the 9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds on their respective maturity dates. As of December&nbsp;30, 2016 and December&nbsp;31,
	2015, $2.3&nbsp;million was recorded within other assets on the consolidated balance sheets related to the debt service reserve fund requirements. The yearly principal payments, which establish a bond sinking fund, will increase the debt service
	reserve fund requirements. The bond premium amount of $2.6&nbsp;million is amortized as a reduction of interest expense over the life of the revenue bonds using the effective interest method.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-23
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Debt Issuance Costs
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Debt issuance costs are deferred and amortized to interest expense over the term of the related debt. Debt issuance costs at December&nbsp;31,
	2016 were $59.0&nbsp;million, net of accumulated amortization of $21.6&nbsp;million. Debt issuance costs at December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $37.6&nbsp;million, net of accumulated amortization of $12.6&nbsp;million. Amortization expense related to debt
	issuance costs, which is reported as interest expense, was $10.8&nbsp;million and $7.1&nbsp;million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015. Estimated amortization of debt issuance costs for the years ending
	December&nbsp;31, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020 and 2021 is $9.3&nbsp;million, $9.7&nbsp;million, $10.0&nbsp;million, $10.4&nbsp;million and $10.2&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	7. Equity
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Preferred Stock
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s
	amended and restated certificate of incorporation provides that up to 10,000,000 shares of preferred stock may be issued. The Board of Directors has the authority to issue preferred stock in one or more series and to fix for each series the voting
	powers (full, limited or none), and the designations, preferences and relative participating, optional or other special rights and qualifications, limitations or restrictions on the stock and the number of shares constituting any series and the
	designations of this series, without any further vote or action by the stockholders.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Common Stock
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;3, 2016, the Company held a Special Meeting of Stockholders, where the Company&#146;s stockholders approved an amendment to the
	Company&#146;s Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation to increase the number of authorized shares of Common Stock from 90,000,000 to 180,000,000 (the &#147;Amendment&#148;). On March&nbsp;3, 2016, the Company filed the Amendment with the
	Secretary of State of the State of Delaware. Holders of the Company&#146;s common stock are entitled to one vote for each share held of record on all matters on which stockholders may vote. There are no preemptive, conversion, redemption or sinking
	fund provisions applicable to shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. In the event of liquidation, dissolution or winding up, holders of the Company&#146;s common stock are entitled to share ratably in the assets available for distribution,
	subject to any prior rights of any holders of preferred stock then outstanding. Delaware law prohibits the Company from paying any dividends unless it has capital surplus or net profits available for this purpose. In addition, the Amended and
	Restated Senior Credit Facility imposes restrictions on the Company&#146;s ability to pay dividends.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Equity Offerings
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;11, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of CRC for total consideration of approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion. As
	consideration for the acquisition, the Company issued 5,975,326 shares of its common stock to certain holders of CRC common stock and repaid CRC&#146;s outstanding indebtedness.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;11, 2015, the Company completed the offering of 5,175,000 shares of common stock (including shares sold pursuant to the exercise
	of the over-allotment option that the Company granted to the underwriters as part of the offering) at a price of $66.50 per share. The net proceeds to the Company from the sale of the shares, after deducting the underwriting discount of
	$12.0&nbsp;million and additional offering-related costs of $0.8&nbsp;million, were $331.3&nbsp;million. The Company used the net offering proceeds to repay outstanding indebtedness and fund acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-24
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage97"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On January&nbsp;12, 2016, the Company completed the offering of 11,500,000 shares of common stock
	(including shares sold pursuant to the exercise of the over-allotment option that the Company granted to the underwriters as part of the offering) at a price of $61.00 per share. The net proceeds to the Company from the sale of the shares, after
	deducting the underwriting discount of $15.8&nbsp;million and additional offering-related costs of $0.7&nbsp;million, were $685.0&nbsp;million. The Company used the net offering proceeds to fund a portion of the purchase price for the acquisition of
	Priory.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;16, 2016, the Company completed the acquisition of Priory for a total purchase price of approximately
	$2.2&nbsp;billion including cash consideration of approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion and the issuance of 4,033,561 shares of our common stock to shareholders of Priory.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	8. Equity-Based Compensation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Equity Incentive
	Plans
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company issues stock-based awards, including stock options, restricted stock and restricted stock units, to certain
	officers, employees and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	directors under the Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. Incentive Compensation Plan (the &#147;Equity Incentive Plan&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, a maximum of
	8,200,000 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock were authorized for issuance as stock options, restricted stock and restricted stock units or other share-based compensation under the Equity Incentive Plan, of which 4,645,213 were available for
	future grant. Stock options may be granted for terms of up to ten years. The Company recognizes expense on all share-based awards on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period of the entire award. Grants to employees generally vest in
	annual increments of 25% each year, commencing one year after the date of grant. The exercise prices of stock options are equal to the most recent closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognized $28.3&nbsp;million, $20.5&nbsp;million and $10.1&nbsp;million in equity-based compensation expense for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there was $51.0&nbsp;million of unrecognized compensation expense related to unvested options, restricted stock and restricted stock units, which is expected to be
	recognized over the remaining weighted average vesting period of 1.2 years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were no warrants
	outstanding and exercisable. The Company recognized a deferred income tax benefit of $10.7&nbsp;million and $8.4&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, related to equity-based compensation expense. The actual
	tax benefit realized from stock options exercised during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 was $0.3&nbsp;million and $4.6&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Stock option activity during 2015 and 2016 was as follows (aggregate intrinsic value in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s estimate of expected volatility for stock options is based upon the volatility of guideline
	companies given the lack of sufficient historical trading experience of the Company&#146;s common stock. The risk-free interest rate is the approximate yield on U.S. Treasury Strips having a life equal to the expected option life on the date of
	grant. The expected life is an estimate of the number of years an option will be held before it is exercised.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-26
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company records a valuation allowance to reduce its net deferred tax assets to the amount that is more
	likely than not to be realized. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the Company carried a valuation allowance against deferred tax assets of $16.0&nbsp;million and $16.6&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The domestic net operating loss carryforwards the Company has acquired for federal net operating loss carryforwards are approximately
	$28.4&nbsp;million and $88.0&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. The foreign net operating loss carryforwards as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 are approximately $92.2&nbsp;million and $14.7&nbsp;million,
	respectively, and have no expiration. In addition, the Company has certain foreign tax credits which do not have an expiration date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
	Company has state net operating loss carryforwards at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 of approximately $223.3&nbsp;million and $213.9&nbsp;million, respectively. These net operating loss carryforwards, if not used to offset future taxable income,
	will expire from 2031 to 2033. In addition, the Company has certain state tax credits which will begin to expire in 2026 if not utilized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Income taxes receivable was $11.7&nbsp;million and $6.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, and was included in
	other current assets in the consolidated balance sheets. Income taxes payable of $0.5&nbsp;million and $7.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 was included in other accrued liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has recorded income taxes payable related to unrecognized tax benefits of $7.8&nbsp;million and $5.4&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, in other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets. A reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of unrecognized income tax benefits net of the federal benefit is as follows (in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-28
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage101"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in its
	consolidated balance sheets. As of December 31, 2016 and 2015, the cumulative amounts recognized were $0.9 million and $1.0 million, respectively. It is possible the amount of unrecognized tax benefit could change in the next twelve months as a
	result of a lapse of the statute of limitations and settlements with taxing authorities; however, management does not anticipate the change will have a material impact on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s uncertain tax positions are related to tax years that remain subject to examination by the relevant taxing authorities. The
	Company and its subsidiaries file income tax returns in federal and in many state and local jurisdictions as well as foreign jurisdictions. The Company may be subject to examination by the Internal Revenue Service (&#147;IRS&#148;) for calendar year
	2014 through 2015. Additionally, any net operating losses that were generated in prior years and utilized in these years may also be subject to examination by the IRS. In foreign jurisdictions, the Company may be subject to examination for calendar
	years 2012 through 2015. Generally, for state tax purposes, the Company&#146;s 2011 through 2015 tax years remain open for examination by the tax authorities. At the date of this report there were no audits or inquires that had progressed
	sufficiently to predict their ultimate outcome.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	One of the Company&#146;s Puerto Rico subsidiaries was granted a tax exemption for which
	a tax credit of up to 15% of eligible payroll expenses is available to offset up to 50% of the income taxes attributed to that entity. The tax exemption will expire on December&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company does not provide for U.S. income taxes on the undistributed earnings of its foreign subsidiaries as it is the Company&#146;s
	intention to utilize those earnings in the foreign operations for an indefinite period of time. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were no undistributed earnings of the foreign subsidiaries. The amount of unrecognized deferred tax liability related to
	these temporary differences is not practicable at this time as this could be significantly impacted by the source location and amount of the distribution, the underlying tax rate already paid on the earnings, foreign withholding taxes, foreign
	currency translation adjustment and the opportunity to use foreign tax credits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	10. Derivatives
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company entered into foreign currency forward contracts during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 in connection with
	(i)&nbsp;acquisitions in the U.K. and (ii)&nbsp;transfers of cash between the U.S. and U.K. under the Company&#146;s cash management and foreign currency risk management programs. Foreign currency forward contracts limit the economic risk of changes
	in the exchange rate between US Dollars (&#147;USD&#148;) and British Pounds (&#147;GBP&#148;) associated with cash transfers. These foreign currency forward contracts did not meet the hedge accounting criteria under Accounting Standards
	Codification 815,
<I>
	Derivatives and Hedging
</I>
	. As such, changes in fair value resulted in gains of $0.5&nbsp;million and losses of $1.9&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively which have been recorded in the
	consolidated statements of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In May 2016, the Company entered into multiple cross currency swap agreements with an aggregate
	notional amount of $650.0&nbsp;million to manage foreign currency risk by effectively converting a portion of its fixed-rate
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	USD-denominated
</FONT>
	senior notes, including the semi-annual interest payments
	thereunder, to fixed-rate
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	GBP-denominated
</FONT>
	debt of &pound;449.3&nbsp;million. The senior notes effectively converted include $150.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 6.125% Senior Notes,
	$300.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 5.125% Senior Notes and $200.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 5.625% Senior Notes. During the term of the swap agreements, the Company will receive semi-annual interest payments in USD
	from the counterparties at fixed interest rates, and the Company will make semi-annual interest payments in GBP to the counterparties at fixed interest rates. The interest payments under the cross-currency swap agreements result in
	&pound;24.7&nbsp;million of annual cash flows, from the Company&#146;s U.K. business being converted to $35.8&nbsp;million (at a 1.45 exchange rate). The interest rates applicable to the GBP interest payments are substantially the same as the
	interest rates in place for the existing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	USD-denominated
</FONT>
	debt. At maturity, the Company will repay the principal amounts listed above in GBP and receive the principal amount in USD.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has designated the cross currency swap agreements as qualifying hedging instruments and is accounting for these as net investment
	hedges. The fair value of the cross currency swap agreements of $73.1&nbsp;million is recorded as an asset within derivative instruments on the consolidated balance sheets. The gains and losses resulting from fair value adjustments to the cross
	currency swap agreements are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income as the swaps are effective in hedging the designated risk. Cash flows related to the cross currency swaps are included in operating activities in the consolidated
	statements of cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-29
</P>

<B>
	11. Fair Value Measurements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The carrying amounts reported for cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, other current assets, accounts payable and other current
	liabilities approximate fair value because of the short-term maturity of these instruments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The carrying amounts and fair values of the
	Company&#146;s Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility, 6.125% Senior Notes, 5.125% Senior Notes, 5.625% Senior Notes, 6.500% Senior Notes, 9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds, derivative instruments and contingent consideration liability as of

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility, 6.125% Senior Notes, 5.125% Senior Notes,
	5.625% Senior Notes, 6.500% Senior Notes and 9.0% and 9.5% Revenue Bonds were categorized as Level&nbsp;2 in the GAAP fair value hierarchy. Fair values were based on trading activity among the Company&#146;s lenders and the average bid and ask price
	as determined using published rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair values of the derivative instruments were categorized as Level&nbsp;2 in the GAAP fair
	value hierarchy and were based on observable market inputs including applicable exchange rates and interest rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of the
	contingent consideration liabilities were categorized as Level&nbsp;3 in the GAAP fair value hierarchy. The contingent consideration liabilities were valued using a probability-weighted discounted cash flow method. This analysis reflected the
	contractual terms of the purchase agreements and utilized assumptions with regard to future earnings, probabilities of achieving such future earnings and a discount rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	12. Leases
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is obligated
	under certain operating leases to rent space for its facilities and other office space. The original terms of the leases typically range from five to ten years, with optional renewal periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

</FONT>
	operating leases with original or remaining
	lease terms in excess of one year were as follows as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 (in thousands):
</P>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	13. Commitments and Contingencies
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is, from time to time, subject to various claims and legal actions that arise in the ordinary course of the Company&#146;s
	business, including claims for damages for personal injuries, medical malpractice, breach of contract, tort and employment related claims. In these actions, plaintiffs request a variety of damages, including, in some instances, punitive and other
	types of damages that may not be covered by insurance. In the opinion of management, the Company is not currently a party to any proceeding that would individually or in the aggregate have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s business,
	financial condition or results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	14. Noncontrolling Interests
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On May&nbsp;2, 2016, the Company opened&nbsp;Crestwyn Behavioral Health, a de novo inpatient psychiatric facility located in Memphis,
	Tennessee. The Company owns 60% of the equity interests in the entity that owns this facility, and two noncontrolling partners each own 20%. The value of the 40% noncontrolling interests is approximately $6.0&nbsp;million and is based on the fair
	value of contributions. The Company consolidates the operations of the facility based on its 60% equity ownership and its control of the entity. The noncontrolling interests are reflected as redeemable noncontrolling interests on the accompanying
	consolidated balance sheets based on a put right that could require the Company to purchase the noncontrolling interests upon the occurrence of a change in control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company completed the acquisition of a controlling interest in&nbsp;Southcoast, an inpatient psychiatric facility
	located in Fairhaven, Massachusetts. The Company owns 75% of the equity interests in the entity that owns this facility. The value of the 25% noncontrolling interest is approximately $9.2&nbsp;million. The Company considered an income approach and
	other valuation methodologies to value the noncontrolling interests. The Company consolidates the operations of the facility based on its 75% equity ownership and its control of the entity. The noncontrolling interests are reflected as redeemable
	noncontrolling interests on the accompanying consolidated balance sheets based on a put right that could require the Company to purchase the noncontrolling interests upon the occurrence of a change in control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	15. Segment Information
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company
	operates in one line of business, which is operating acute inpatient psychiatric facilities, specialty treatment facilities, residential treatment centers and facilities providing outpatient behavioral healthcare services. As management reviews the
	operating results of its facilities in the United States (the &#147;U.S. Facilities&#148;) and its facilities in the United Kingdom (the &#147;U.K. Facilities&#148;) separately to assess performance and make decisions, the Company&#146;s operating
	segments include its U.S. Facilities and U.K. Facilities. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the U.S. Facilities included 208 behavioral healthcare facilities with approximately 8,500 beds in 39 states and Puerto Rico, and the U.K. Facilities included 365
	behavioral healthcare facilities with approximately 8,600 beds in the U.K.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-31
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage104"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Segment EBITDA is defined as income from continuing operations before provision for income taxes, equity-based
	compensation expense, debt extinguishment costs, gain on foreign currency derivatives, transaction-related expenses, interest expense and depreciation and amortization. The Company uses Segment EBITDA as an analytical indicator to measure the
	performance of the Company&#146;s segments and to develop strategic objectives and operating plans for those segments. Segment EBITDA is commonly used as an analytical indicator within the health care industry, and also serves as a measure of
	leverage capacity and debt service ability. Segment EBITDA should not be considered as a measure of financial performance under generally accepted accounting principles, and the items excluded from Segment EBITDA are significant components in
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-32
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage105"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D289026D10K_HTM_INDEX">
	Index to Financial Statements
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	understanding and assessing financial performance. Because Segment EBITDA is not a measurement determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and is thus susceptible to
	varying calculations, Segment EBITDA, as presented, may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Assets include property and equipment for the U.S. Facilities of $1.0&nbsp;billion, U.K. Facilities of $1.7&nbsp;billion and corporate and other of $27.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Assets include property
	and equipment for the U.S. Facilities of $832.2&nbsp;million, U.K. Facilities of $824.4&nbsp;million and corporate and other of $52.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	16. Employee Benefit Plans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Defined Contribution
	Plan
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company maintains a qualified defined contribution 401(k) plan covering substantially all of its employees in the U.S.
	The Company may, at its discretion, make contributions to the plan. The Company contributed $0.1&nbsp;million to the 401(k) plan for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Partnerships in Care Pension Plan
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As part of the acquisition of Partnerships in Care on July&nbsp;1, 2014, the Company assumed a frozen contributory defined benefit retirement
	plan (&#147;Partnerships in Care Pension Plan&#148;) covering substantially all of the employees of Partnerships in Care and its subsidiaries prior to May&nbsp;1, 2005 at which time, the Partnerships in Care Plan was frozen to new participants.
	Effective May 2015, the active participants no longer accrue benefits. The benefits under the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan were primarily based on years of service and final average earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company accounts for the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan in accordance with ASC
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	715-30
</FONT>
	&#147;Compensation &#151; Defined Benefit Plans&#148;, (&#147;ASC
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	715-30&#148;).
</FONT>
	In accordance with ASC
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	715-30,
</FONT>
	the Company recognizes the unfunded liability of the
	Partnerships in Care Pension Plan on the Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheet and unrecognized gains (losses) and prior service credits (costs) as changes in other comprehensive income (loss). The measurement date of the Partnerships in Care
	Pension Plan&#146;s assets and liabilities coincides with the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end.
</FONT>
	The Company&#146;s pension benefit obligation is measured using actuarial calculations that incorporate discount rates,
	rate of compensation increases, when applicable, expected long-term returns on plan assets and consider expected age of retirement and mortality. Expected return on plan assets is determined by using the specific asset distribution at the
	measurement date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table summarizes the funded status (unfunded liability) of the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan based
	upon actuarial valuations prepared as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 (in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-33
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognizes changes in the funded status of the pension plan as a direct increase or decrease to
	stockholders&#146; equity through accumulated other comprehensive income. The accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) related to the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 was $(7.4) million
	($(6.1) million net of taxes), $2.6&nbsp;million ($1.7&nbsp;million net of taxes) and $(2.8) million ($(2.2)&nbsp;million net of taxes), respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The trustees of the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan are required to invest assets in the best interest of the Partnerships in Care Pension
	Plan&#146;s members and also ensure liquid assets are available to make benefit payments as they become due. Performance of the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan&#146;s assets are monitored quarterly, at a minimum, and asset allocations are adjusted
	as needed. The Partnerships in Care Pension Plan&#146;s weighted-average asset allocations by asset category as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 were as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the Partnerships in Care Pension Plan cash and cash equivalents were
	classified as Level&nbsp;1 in the GAAP fair value hierarchy. Fair values were based on utilizing quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets. The U.K. government obligations, annuity contracts, equity securities, debt
	securities and other investments were classified as Level&nbsp;2 in the GAAP fair value hierarchy. Fair values were based on data points that are observable, such as quoted prices, interest rates and yield curves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

</P>

	components of accumulated other comprehensive loss are as follows (in thousands):

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	18. Quarterly Information (Unaudited)
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The tables below present summarized unaudited quarterly results of operations for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015. Management
	believes that all necessary adjustments have been included in the amounts stated below for a fair presentation of the results of operations for the periods presented when read in conjunction with the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements
	for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015. Results of operations for a particular quarter are not necessarily indicative of results of operations for an annual period and are not predictive of future periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes debt extinguishment costs of $10.0&nbsp;million, or $6.8&nbsp;million net of taxes, in connection with the redemption of $88.3&nbsp;million of the 12.875% Senior Notes on September&nbsp;21, 2015. On
	November&nbsp;1, 2015, the Company redeemed all of the outstanding $9.2&nbsp;million principal amount of the 12.875% Senior Notes and incurred additional debt extinguishment cost of $0.8&nbsp;million.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	19. Financial Information for the Company and Its Subsidiaries
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company conducts substantially all of its business through its subsidiaries. The 6.125% Senior Notes, 5.125% Senior Notes, 5.625% Senior
	Notes and 6.500% senior notes are jointly and severally guaranteed on an unsecured senior basis by all of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries that guarantee the Company&#146;s obligations under the Amended and Restated Senior Credit Facility. Presented
	below is condensed consolidating financial information for the Company and its subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014. The information segregates the parent company (Acadia
	Healthcare Company, Inc.), the combined wholly-owned subsidiary guarantors, the combined
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-guarantor
</FONT>
	subsidiaries and eliminations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	F-35
</P>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">

<EFX_EXPERTS_CONSENT>
<A NAME="FIS_EXPERTS_CONSENT"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	Consent of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We consent to the incorporation by reference in the following Registration Statements:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(1) Form S-3 (No. 333-196611) pertaining to the Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. registration of shares of common stock;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(2) Form S-8 (No. 333-177990) pertaining to the Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. Incentive Compensation Plan;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(3) Form S-8 (No. 333-190232) pertaining to the Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. Incentive Compensation Plan;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(4) Form S-8 (No. 333-211505) pertaining to the Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. Incentive Compensation Plan; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(5) Post-Effective Amendment No.&nbsp;1 to Form S-4 on Form S-8 (No. 333-175523) pertaining to the PHC, Inc. 2004 Non-Employee Director Stock Option Plan, the
	PHC, Inc. 2003 Stock Purchase and Option Plan, the PHC, Inc. 1995 Employee Stock Purchase Plan and the PHC, Inc. 1993 Stock Purchase and Option Plan of our reports dated February&nbsp;24, 2017, with respect to the consolidated financial statements
	of Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. and the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting of Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc., included in this Annual Report (Form 10-K) of Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:56%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	/s/ Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young, LLP
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Nashville, Tennessee

<B>
	EXHIBIT 31.1
